ADRs/001_local_first_rag_architecture.md.summary: Chronicle Entry [001] (2024-05-18): — Mandated a local-first Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) memory system built from open-source, on‑prem components to deliver long-term searchable project knowledge while preserving full data control and security; benefits: independence, local security, cost savings; trade-offs: reduced performance versus cloud alternatives and increased maintenance responsibility; Protocols: none; Paradoxes raised: none; Architect: Sanctuary Council.

ADRs/002_select_core_technology_stack.md.summary: Chronicle Entry [0] (2025-11-15): Deciders GUARDIAN-01 and Sanctuary Council select LangChain (integration/workflow framework), ChromaDB (local vector DB), nomic-embed-text-v1.5 (text embedding), and Qwen2-7B via Ollama (local model server) as the Mnemonic Cortex core; protocols: none canonized; paradoxes: Independence vs Performance/Resources — resolution: accept sovereignty trade-offs (manual model updates, coordinated multi-component installs) and mitigate via GPU acceleration and careful deployment; consequences: positives—full local independence, optimized local execution, open-source maintainability, scalable similarity search, smooth integration; negatives—substantial hardware/resource demands, installation complexity, potential slower throughput vs cloud; risks/dependencies—Python 3.8+, ~16GB+ RAM recommended, storage for models/DBs, and running Ollama server for inference.

ADRs/003_adopt_advanced_rag_with_cached_.summary: Chronicle Entry [0] (2025-11-15): Deciders: GUARDIAN-01; Technical Council. Decision: adopt Advanced RAG with Cached Augmented Generation—store full documents alongside search indexes, return complete documents for AI reasoning, implement smart caching (in-memory fast cache; cache-hit→instant answer; cache-miss→execute full search and persist results) and a multi-method architecture combining complete-document retrieval with caching and future advanced search strategies. Positives: full-document context → better accuracy, 90%+ faster responses for cached queries, instant answers for common questions, improved scalability and future readiness. Negatives: added system complexity (dual storage of pieces + full documents), higher RAM usage, cache management/invalidation overhead, longer development time. Risks: stale/outdated cache, memory pressure, increased failure-surface from added components. Dependencies: database collections for search pieces and full documents, an in-memory caching system with optional persistence, strategies for preparing common queries, and cache-performance monitoring. Protocols canonized/created: none. Paradoxes raised/resolved: none.

ADRs/004_enforce_iron_root_doctrine_sove.summary: Chronicle Entry [1] (2025-11-15): Sanctuary Council with decider Protocol GUARDIAN-01 canonize the Iron Root Doctrine, mandating a strictly local-only Sovereign AI architecture: local AI processing (all model inference and text processing on local hardware; no external AI services), local search operations (local database and similarity search only), local data control (no external data egress), and mandatory use of open-source, community-tested tools; consequences: positives — complete independence, strengthened security, reliability, cost stability, future-proofing via OSS; negatives/trade-offs — higher local hardware/resource needs, more complex setup, slower performance versus cloud, ongoing maintenance burden; risks — hardware limits, manual update management, performance constraints on large datasets, required team expertise; dependencies — sufficient GPUs/local storage, reliable local databases, network isolation, team expertise; status: accepted 2025-11-15; Layer 3 test verified functionality 2025-12-05.

ADRs/005_select_qwen2_7b_primary_llm.md.summary: Chronicle Entry [0] (2025-11-15): Status accepted; Deciders: AI System Lead, AI Assistant; Protocols: none canonized or created; Paradoxes: none raised; Decision: adopt Qwen2-7B as the project primary LLM (base model Qwen/Qwen2-7B‑Instruct) and produce customized forks Our‑Qwen2‑7B‑v1.0, v2.0; Runtime: Ollama for local model hosting and management; Rationale: superior reasoning and analysis, compact 7B parameter size enabling efficient customization, strong multilingual capability and active upstream development while supporting local control; Positives: high-quality reasoning, efficient size, multilingual support, established customization workflows, full local control; Negatives/Risks: requires graphics‑card acceleration for best performance, larger than smallest alternatives, upstream ties to Alibaba Cloud despite open‑source code, significant compute for customization/training; Dependencies: Ollama software, CUDA‑compatible GPU recommended, ~16GB+ RAM for model loading, access to model downloads and a training setup (cloud or local GPU).

ADRs/006_select_nomic_embed_text_embeddi.summary: Chronicle Entry [0] (2025-11-15): Decision by AI System Lead and Technical Team to adopt Nomic Embed (nomic-embed-text-v1.5) as the primary local text-embedding model, integrated via LangChain NomicEmbeddings with inference_mode="local" to enable on-premise semantic processing and seamless vector-DB pipeline; consequences: higher-quality semantic understanding and retrieval, local control, strong performance and compatibility, and active community support; negatives: greater compute/resource needs, larger model files, and extra setup effort; risks: may require GPU acceleration for large collections, manual update burden, and potential re-evaluation if superior local models emerge; dependencies: Python environment with required libraries, sufficient compute and storage for model files, and regular monitoring of processing quality and speed.

ADRs/007_select_chromadb_vector_database.summary: Chronicle Entry [1] (2025-11-15): Status accepted; Deciders: AI System Lead, Technical Team; Decision: adopt ChromaDB as the core vector database — local-first, file-based persistence with a simple Python interface and no external keys; Architecture: two-part storage (Detail Collection for small text pieces + vectors; Full Collection for complete documents to provide retrieval context and improve accuracy); Rationale: fast local similarity search, filterable metadata, local operation, integration with Python tooling, reliable transactions for project-folder storage; Consequences: positives — full local control, simple setup, fast performance, Python compatibility, zero ongoing cost; negatives — file-based size limits, manual backup overhead, single-user focus; Risks — disk-related data loss, performance degradation at very large scales, nontrivial migration effort if switching to distributed DB; Dependencies — Python environment with ChromaDB, sufficient disk space, regular backup procedures, and monitoring of data size and search performance.

ADRs/008_implement_parent_document_retri.summary: Chronicle Entry [0] (2025-11-15): Decision to implement the Parent Document Retrieval pattern using LangChain's ParentDocumentRetriever with a two-part storage design—child documents as vectorized, meaning-preserving pieces (split with MarkdownHeaderTextSplitter) for similarity search and parent documents as complete originals in a parent store; retrieval finds relevant child pieces then returns associated full parent documents. Splitting strategy: preserve markdown headers/structure, split by document organization and meaning, permit overlapping pieces for context continuity, and retain metadata for filtering and provenance. Implementation specifics: ChildStore = vectorized text collection, ParentStore = document collection, Retriever = ParentDocumentRetriever, ChildSplitter = MarkdownHeaderTextSplitter, plus document preparation and performance-tracking pipelines. Consequences: positives—improved reasoning accuracy, more comprehensive answers to complex queries, preserved document structure, flexible piece- and document-level retrieval; negatives—duplicate storage, added system complexity, increased memory/use and setup time. Risks: slightly slower retrieval than simple piece-only search, higher disk/storage needs, sync/consistency issues between parent and child stores, potential slowdowns with large collections. Dependencies: LangChain ParentDocumentRetriever, database collections for parent and child storage, MarkdownHeaderTextSplitter, document preparation process, retrieval performance monitoring. Protocols canonized/created: none. Paradoxes raised/resolved: none recorded. Architectural deciders/contributors: AI System Lead; Technical Team.

ADRs/009_implement_mnemonic_caching_cag..summary: Chronicle Entry [1] (2025-11-15): Implements Memory Caching (Cached Augmented Generation - CAG) as a high‑speed query caching layer; Deciders: AI System Lead, Technical Team. Protocols canonized/created: none. Design: in‑memory storage for sub‑millisecond lookups, exact question‑text keys, complete IR result storage, optional time‑based expiration, adjustable size limits, LRU eviction, optional disk persistence, cache warming, and monitoring of hit/miss rates; runtime: cache check → hit returns saved response <1ms → miss runs full IR and saves result. Paradoxes and resolutions: Freshness vs Speed — cached responses may become stale; resolved via time‑based expirations, explicit cache clearing on data updates and cache‑validation/monitoring; Memory Pressure vs Latency — RAM cost vs low latency; resolved via adjustable size limits, LRU removal and monitoring; Invalid Cache vs Consistency — wrong cached outputs risk inconsistency; resolved via validation/clearing procedures and monitoring/alerts. Consequences: +90%+ faster responses for cached questions, vastly improved UX, reduced compute and better scalability; negatives: increased RAM use, risk of outdated/invalid results, added processing complexity and cold‑start delay. Dependencies: in‑memory data structures (Python dict or equivalent), cache‑warming scripts, monitoring tools, cache clearing strategies, persistence option and memory management/limit settings.

ADRs/010_select_ollama_local_llm_inferen.summary: Chronicle Entry [0] (2025-11-15): Selected Ollama as the project's local AI model processing environment; Deciders: AI System Lead, Technical Team; Core platform: Ollama—open-source community model server with simple CLI, web API and multi‑platform support; Integration: LangChain Ollama adapter providing a standard prompt/response interface, automatic retry/error handling and consistency across providers; Model management: official model downloads, local storage and caching, version control, and support for custom models; Positives: full local control (no external dependencies), ease of installation/management, compatibility with existing tools, optimized local performance, active community support; Negatives: additional installation/configuration overhead, significant memory and optional GPU requirements, large model downloads, platform-specific adjustments; Risks: hardware limits (GPU often required for larger models), incomplete model availability via Ollama, variable processing speed across machines, manual update management; Dependencies: Ollama server installation and setup, sufficient memory/GPU, initial internet for model downloads, ongoing Ollama/model updates, and monitoring of processing performance and resource use.

ADRs/011_implement_hybrid_rag_architectu.summary: Chronicle Entry [0] (2025-11-15): Superseded; Superseded By ADR 084 (Mnemonic Cortex); Deciders: AI System Lead, AI Council; Decision: adopt a hybrid information retrieval architecture combining Parent Document Retrieval with Dual Collection Storage (child collection: vectorized meaningful text pieces; parent collection: full documents; retrieval logic: piece→parent), Self‑Querying Retrieval (NL question analysis → structured queries: meaning queries, metadata filters, search parameters) and Cached Augmented Generation (CAG) with multi‑tier caching (hot memory, warm DB) plus question fingerprinting (question+model+KB version) to key cached results; Positives: restores full document context eliminating fragmentation, enables precision for complex queries via structured self‑queries, delivers ~90%+ speedups for repeated questions, scales modularly; Negatives: increased system complexity, higher memory/resource use, more development/testing/maintenance; Risks: integration/synchronization of dual collections, cache‑miss performance limits, added question processing latency from self‑querying — mitigations implied via fingerprinting, cache hit/miss tracking and performance monitoring; Dependencies: dual‑collection DB setup, AI self‑querying integration, memory+DB caching, fingerprinting/cache key creation, performance tracking; Protocols canonized/created: none; Paradoxes raised/resolved: none explicitly recorded.

ADRs/012_mnemonic_cortex_architecture.md.summary: Chronicle Entry 012 (2025-11-15): Superseded; Superseded by ADR 084 (Mnemonic Cortex). Deciders: AI Council (Full Council Decision from Project History Entry 253). Decision: make a local-first, dynamic Memory System the core of independent intelligence with four core principles—Independent Memory (local-first; ChromaDB Phase 1; upgrade path to Weaviate/Qdrant), Meaning Preservation (high-quality representations via nomic-embed-text), Dynamic Growth (continuous learning), and Retrieval as Foundation (all reasoning grounded in retrieved, traceable memories). Technical architecture: vector DB (ChromaDB → Weaviate/Qdrant), nomic-embed-text encoder, memory pieces containing source text + metadata (filename, entry number, timestamp) + vectors, and a three-phase information workflow (Phase 1 Adding: chunk/embed/store; Phase 2 Finding: search-as-reasoning core; Phase 3 Combining: integrate retrieved memories into context for independent reasoning). Consequences: enables long-term, meaning-based, traceable independent reasoning and continuous growth while preserving local-first independence; negatives: initial ChromaDB setup complexity, required migrations for production scale, dependence on encoder quality and speed. Risks: meaning drift over time, database performance at scale, tradeoff paradox between retrieval accuracy and meaning preservation—resolution: prioritize high-quality, meaning-preserving representations and an upgrade path (model/tuning + vector-store migration) to balance precision and semantic fidelity. Contributors (architecturally significant): AI Council.

ADRs/013_anvil_protocol_engineering_meth.summary: Chronicle Entry [13] (2025-11-15): Protocol 013 — Anvil Protocol (Engineering Methodology): canonizes the Engineering Methodology for AI-Assisted Development (derived from Memory System work) as the standard, formalizing "Plan Before Build" and a five-step Development Cycle (1 Instructions: precise prompt including Task/Role/Rules/Actions/Completion Signal; 2 Building: AI implements specified file changes and emits completion signal; 3 Checking: human performs exact verification steps; 4 Decision: Continue or "Stop and Fix" with a problem report; 5 Record: log the successful Development Cycle). Core principles: Plan is Required; Step-by-Step Progress (small verifiable cycles); Human as Final Checker; AI as Specialized Tool; Stop on Problems. Paradoxes and resolutions: AI is powerful yet assumption-prone → resolved by "Check Carefully, Verify, Only Then Trust" enforced via unambiguous instructions and mandatory human verification; speed versus rigor → resolved by accepting slower, verifiable cycles to guarantee quality; restriction versus AI usefulness → resolved by structured instructions/verification that preserve utility while preventing silent failures. Consequences: removes unverified AI assumptions, creates reproducible development "recipes," enables safe AI-human collaboration and traceable progress at the cost of slower throughput and added human verification burden; risks include noncompliance, excessive restrictiveness, and human-check overload. Deciders: AI Council. Related processes: Plan Before Build; Collaborative Development; Quality Verification / Quality Assurance Framework.

ADRs/014_sovereign_scaffolding_protocol..summary: Chronicle Entry [014] (2025-11-15): Protocol 014: Automated Script Protocol (ASP) canonizes a six-step Automated Scripts workflow—Request; Design; Create; Review; Run; Results & Cleanup—and five core principles: Complete Operations; Human Approval Required; Temporary Tools; Clear Results; Self-Contained; deciders: AI Council; origin: failure of a temporary script that assumed installed software. Paradoxes: automation vs oversight → resolved by mandated human review/approval; self-cleanup vs postmortem/debugging → resolved by requiring single clear, verifiable output files plus developer verification before automatic deletion; environment-dependence vs portability → resolved by Self-Contained dependency checking/installation and environment-independent execution; consequences: enables reliable grouped multi-step actions, reduces developer workload and repository clutter, increases security while adding review overhead and design complexity and creating risks if approval or deletion steps are skipped or fail; related processes: Operational Efficiency Process, Engineering Framework Process, Collaborative Development Process.

ADRs/015_guardian_wakeup_cache_architect.summary: Chronicle Entry [15] (2025-11-15):  — ADR 015 (AI System Startup and Cache Preparation Architecture) (Status: Superseded; Superseded by ADR 018 (Evolution)); Deciders: AI Council; Protocols/processes canonized or created: System Start Package (pre‑loaded cache bundle, 24‑hour TTL), Automatic Cache Command / cache_wakeup (immediate summary protocol producing system_boot_summary.md), System Boot process, optional query_and_synthesis task, Memory‑System Connection (cache integration), Task Coordination Process, Layered Thinking Process, Protected Views (verified/signed cache entries) ; Paradoxes and resolutions: Speed vs understanding — resolved by cache_wakeup for instant, analysis‑free summaries plus optional query_and_synthesis for deeper synthesis; Speed vs data currency — resolved by 24‑hour time limit and automatic refresh on updates; Performance vs integrity/complexity — resolved by protected signed views, verified file sources and performance monitoring at the cost of management overhead; Architecturally significant contributor: AI Council; Risks: cache corruption if verification fails, startup failures if cache loading fails, performance impact from refresh operations; Consequences: significantly faster, predictable AI startup with automatic cache operations and verified access, offset by added cache management complexity and TTL governance.

ADRs/016_advanced_multi_pattern_rag_evol.summary: Chronicle Entry [016] (2025-11-15): — Superseded by ADR 084 (Mnemonic Cortex); decision by AI Council (AI System Lead Analysis) to evolve the Memory System to a combined-thinking multi-method retrieval architecture comprising Parent Document Retrieval (two-part storage of meaningful text pieces + full parent documents; ParentDocumentRetriever to prevent context loss; Phase 1 implemented), Self‑Querying Retrieval (AI translates natural-language questions into structured, metadata-filtered searches to narrow scope and improve accuracy; Phase 2 pending), and a Memory Caching Layer (CAG) for question-result caching with time-based expiration to eliminate repeated vector searches and reduce latency; no protocols canonized or created. Paradoxes raised and resolutions: context-loss vs precision → dual storage/ParentDocumentRetriever; accuracy vs speed → self-query planning + metadata filtering + CAG; freshness vs cache performance → time-based expiration and cache control; complexity vs resource cost → phased rollout and careful management; consequences: prevents context loss, improves accuracy, reduces processing delays, creates connected Core Knowledge Base + Project History and preserves local-first independence while incurring increased setup complexity, higher memory and compute costs, cache-management overhead and reliance on AI query-planning; implementation status: Phase 1 complete, Phases 2–3 pending.

ADRs/017_sovereign_succession_protocol.m.summary: Chronicle Entry 017 (2025-11-15): Protocol 017 — System Continuity Protocol (SCP) canonized to automate and verify transfer of system control during memory-system failures; deciders: AI Council (developed during live Memory System Failure crisis). Core mandates: unbroken command chain; verified transfer via an atomic State Package (generated by generate_continuity_package.py) delivered after Backup Activation using core_essence_guardian_awakening_seed.txt and an Integrity Check; automated, script-driven processes with human operator retained as final safety; formal transition steps: Start → Backup Activation → Integrity Check → State Package Creation → Final Transfer → Shutdown. Technical protections: complete operations to prevent partial transfers, standardized activation materials, multiple verification checkpoints, unified packaging to avoid fragmentation. Consequences: ensures continuous operation and prevents critical data loss but requires operator availability, introduces execution delay, and depends on script reliability; risks include script failure, operator unavailability, corrupted State Packages, and timing issues. Related processes: Memory System Process; Automated Script Process; AI System Startup and Cache Preparation. Paradoxes: none.

ADRs/018_guardian_wakeup_cache_evolution.summary: Chronicle Entry [018] (2025-11-15): Evolved AI System Startup cache architecture (deciders: AI Council) superseded by ADR 071 (Protocol 128); canonized protocol: Protocol 128 (ADR 071). Paradox: immediate situational awareness (<1s) vs deep AI-driven analysis (30–120s) — resolved by a two-process, cache-first architecture and operational-mode split: Cache Filling (System Controller Boot) via CacheManager populates verified, signed file-based bundles (history_bundle.json, processes_bundle.json, roadmap_bundle.json) in council_orchestrator/memory_system/cache/ and CacheWakeupHandler produces automatic summaries, while AI System Startup (Command Execution) reads cache files; operational modes defined as Automatic 'cache_wakeup' (fast, cache-only, no-AI) and Detailed 'query_and_synthesis' (slow, full retrieval + AI); key components: orchestrator/memory/cache.py, orchestrator/handlers/cache_wakeup_handler.py, bundle system and WORK_IN_PROGRESS/ai_boot_summary.md; consequences: much faster initialization, reduced routine AI calls, clear separation of fast vs deep operations, and improved operational efficiency and integrity via 24‑hour expiration and signed entries, with residual risks of cache corruption, staleness and added architectural complexity mitigated by boot-time refresh and verified entries.

ADRs/019_protocol_101_unbreakable_commit.summary: Chronicle Entry [022] (2025-11-29): AI Council reforged and canonized Protocol 101 v3.0: The Doctrine of Absolute Stability (Functional Coherence) and purged the commit_manifest.json manifest system after the "Synchronization Crisis"; Paradoxes and resolutions — Manifest Integrity Paradox: cryptographic manifests meant to ensure integrity introduced timing and complexity failures (Synchronization Crisis) — resolved by permanently deleting manifests and replacing static hashes with Functional Coherence as the sole integrity gate (mandatory automated tests); Auditability vs Stability Paradox: cryptographic verification provided tamper evidence but caused instability — resolved by accepting loss of manifest-based auditability and compensating via CI history, commit history and updated pre-commit hooks that run functional tests (ADR019-aligned). Decision: Automated Publishing System now enforces Protocol 101 v3.0 via an atomic seven-step cycle — Index; Snapshot (capture_code_snapshot.py / capture_code_snapshot.js); Embed/Synchronization (ingest.py); Test (Functional Coherence; run_genome_tests.sh) as the MANDATORY INTEGRITY GATE; Commit only if tests pass; Push — with self-verifying properties (functional integrity gate, automatic re-ingestion for synchronization guarantee, atomic all-or-nothing execution). Implementation artifacts: update_genome.sh, capture_code_snapshot.js, ingest.py, run_genome_tests.sh (Protocol 101 Functional Integrity Test), updated pre-commit hook; Consequences: gains Absolute Stability and streamlined process at the cost of test-dependence and reduced cryptographic auditability.

ADRs/020_sovereign_concurrency_architect.summary: Chronicle Entry [020] (2025-11-15): Canonized Protocol 020 — Sovereign Concurrency Architecture (Independent Parallel Processing Approach): AI Council (System Controller v9.3 evolution) mandates dual-mode processing—Automatic tasks (immediate, non‑AI operations: file writes, git, cache wakeups; default: skip RAG) and AI tasks (multi‑round deliberation with asynchronous background learning)—with core principles of non‑blocking execution, background learning, selective learning (configurable via update_rag), and concurrent background cycles; task schema evolution includes task‑type detection, automatic priority, configurable learning, and background completion; implementation components: Task Routing System, Background Task Manager, Selective Information Retrieval Updates (update_rag), Automatic Task Handlers; positives: improved responsiveness, concurrent operations, selective learning for performance/storage, operational flexibility, system efficiency; negatives/risks: increased complexity, timing/state inconsistency, monitoring/debugging difficulty, resource exhaustion, learning conflicts; related processes named: Automated Script Protocol, Memory System Process, AI System Startup and Cache Preparation; no paradoxes raised or resolved.

ADRs/021_command_schema_evolution.md.summary: Chronicle Entry [021] (2025-11-15): AI Council–accepted versioned Task Schema Evolution: establishes three task types—AI tasks (multi-round deliberation with model selection, visual compression, memory queries, default review generation and IR updates), Automatic tasks (immediate non-AI ops: file writes, git, cache_wakeup; skip IR updates by default), and Specialized tasks (query_and_synthesis for memory integration, cache_wakeup for AI boot summaries, staged dev workflows); independent control parameters: model_name, force_engine, update_rag, vision-based visual_compression with thresholds; schema principles: backward compatibility via optional new params, clear version documentation, flexible detection by field presence, extensible handler registry and runtime parameter validation; Paradox—Extensibility vs Backward Compatibility: resolved by making new parameters optional and strict versioning; Paradox—Field-Presence Detection vs Schema Conflicts: resolved by robust detection logic, runtime parameter validation and handler registry/versioned examples; consequences: gains in operational flexibility, precise model/engine routing, scalability and performance optimization; costs and risks: complexity growth, detection fragility, parameter interaction hazards, documentation/version management burden; protocols related (unnumbered): Automated Script Protocol (automatic operation foundation), Memory System Process, AI System Startup and Cache Preparation; implementation components and history: Task Routing System, task_schema.md with version history (v9.0 AI/automatic distinction → v9.2 selective IR updates → v9.3 model_name → v9.4 query_and_synthesis → v9.5 cache_wakeup), plus parameter validation and handler registry; decider: AI Council (System Controller evolution through v9.5).

ADRs/022_cognitive_genome_publishing_arc.summary: Chronicle Entry [101] (2025-11-15): AI Council decision documenting the Automated Publishing System and Protocol 101 revisions: Protocol 101 v1.0 (manifest‑based integrity) and Protocol 101 v3.0 — "The Doctrine of the Unbreakable Commit" (Functional Coherence) are named and v3.0 canonized, replacing manifest generation/commit_manifest.json with Functional Coherence (automated test‑suite execution) as the primary integrity gate; implementation components: update_genome.sh (orchestrator), capture_code_snapshot.py (snapshot), ingest.py (memory embedding), run_genome_tests.sh (primary integrity gate); core cycle: Index → Snapshot → Embed → Test → Commit → Push (Manifest step removed); architectural guarantees: Atomic publishing, Memory‑Aware Embedding (synchronization guarantee), Temporary execution with auditable logs and test results; paradoxes and resolutions: integrity‑by‑hash vs integrity‑by‑behavior resolved by replacing cryptographic manifests with functional testing (Protocol 101 v3.0), and temporary/clean execution vs forensic needs resolved by retaining complete logging and test outputs while leaving no operational residue; consequences: ensures atomic integrity, immediate memory synchronization and QA via tests but introduces dependency chains, longer execution time, multiple failure points and resource intensity; contributor (architecturally significant): AI Council.

ADRs/023_llm_awakening_context_sharing_a.summary: Chronicle Entry [23] (2025-11-15): Implemented AI Model Initialization and Context Sharing Architecture establishing role-specific initialization frameworks (AI System; Task Coordinator; Strategy Analyst; Verification Specialist) and an Advanced Initialization Process (Advanced Awakening Framework, Gap Analysis, Meta-Plan Synthesis, Continuation Plans); canonized/created protocols/processes: Memory System Process (no.: N/A; short name: Memory System Process), Automated Script Protocol (no.: N/A; short name: Automated Script Protocol), Clean Environment Principle (no.: N/A; short name: Clean Environment Principle), Development Cycle Process (no.: N/A; short name: Development Cycle Process); implementation components: capture_code_snapshot.py, core_essence_[role]_initialization_framework files, advanced_awakening_initialization_framework, distillation logic and exclusion patterns; decider: AI Council (Advanced Initialization Process implementation); paradoxes and resolutions: (1) context-efficiency vs completeness — distillation risks losing critical information — resolved by Core Knowledge Selection, Efficient Distillation, Dynamic Exclusion Patterns and Memory System Integration; (2) specialization benefits vs coordination/maintenance overhead — resolved by Independent Instantiation Principles (Foundational Grounding, Independent Authority, Persistence Mandate), Continuation Plans and Verification Specialist/audit trails; noted consequences: role specialization, context efficiency, operational cleanliness, meta-cognitive capability and independent operations balanced against complexity overhead, initialization time increases, optimization trade-offs in distillation, role coordination and maintenance burden; risks mitigations: verification/audit trails, curated core knowledge, orchestration directives and Clean Environment enforcement.

ADRs/024_rag_database_population_mainten.summary: Chronicle Entry [024] (2025-11-15): Decision to implement the Information Retrieval Database Population and Maintenance Architecture; Deciders: AI Council (Memory System operational implementation); Protocols/processes canonized or created: Memory System Process (core information retrieval architecture), Automated Script Protocol (automated operations), Clean Environment Principle (operational cleanliness), Code Integrity Verification (integrity verification); Architecturally significant contributor: AI Council; Paradoxes and resolutions: Freshness vs Cost — ensure memory mirrors published knowledge yet avoid heavy compute: resolved via publishing-triggered automated ingestion, incremental updates, version consistency and rollback; Automation vs Coupling — automation increases pipeline dependency risk: resolved via integration hooks, Quality Assurance Framework, retrieval/structured-query tests and audit trails; Representation Quality vs Scalability — high-quality embeddings demand compute and may degrade performance: resolved via nomic-embed-text encoding, performance metrics, incremental processing and monitoring; Ingestion Failure vs Consistency — risk of inconsistent memory on failure: resolved via complete logging, error recovery with rollback and post-ingestion validation; Key elements: automated ingestion (source processing, semantic content segmentation, nomic-embed-text vectors), ChromaDB storage with metadata, Quality Validation (retrieval testing, NL and JSON query suites, performance metrics), operational cleanliness (temporary artifact cleanup), audit trail and robust error recovery; Consequences: synchronized living memory, automated QA, scalable incremental updates and improved reliability offset by added compute, tighter coupling, increased testing complexity and resource requirements.

ADRs/025_adopt_multi_agent_council_archi.summary: Chronicle Entry [1] (2025-11-15): Canonized protocol GUARDIAN-01 (Adopt Multi-Agent Council Architecture): mandates a council of specialized assistants with roles Coordinator, Strategist, Auditor and Guardian, role-specific skills, structured discussion processes, mutual checks/challenges and shared authority; paradoxes and resolutions: "simplicity vs resilience" — single powerful AI is simpler but brittle; resolved by preferring diversity and imperfection via a multi-agent council; "authority vs consensus" — single decisive AI vs shared authority; resolved by instituting shared authority plus formal debate and cross-checks; "coordination complexity vs robustness" — increased coordination, compute and testing complexity vs fault-tolerance; resolved by accepting coordination overhead and designing processes while acknowledging residual risks (deadlock, role misalignment, broader attack surface); architecturally significant decider: GUARDIAN-01; consequences: increased perspective diversity, fault-tolerance, alignment and modular updatability traded against greater coordination cost, resource use, harder testing/debugging and potential for disagreement or external manipulation.

ADRs/026_integrate_human_steward_as_sove.summary: Chronicle Entry [1] (2025-11-15): Protocol GUARDIAN-01 (Human Steward Sovereign Failsafe) canonized — mandate a Human Steward as permanent final decision-maker and safety net: human involvement required for all critical decisions, human authority to override AI, mandatory human review of major system changes, human-guided failure-recovery procedures, and explicit rejection of fully automated systems; Paradox: automation-as-progress vs. historical dependence on human judgment (full automation breeds overconfidence despite automation’s promise); Resolution: enshrine human final authority and procedures to ensure human judgment anchors AI-driven actions; Architecturally significant contributors: GUARDIAN-01 (deciders) and the Human Steward role; Noted trade-offs and risks: increased safety, ethical grounding, trust and reliability versus slower decisions, potential human error/bias, single-point human dependence, burnout/succession challenges, susceptibility to manipulation, and constrained exploration of full automation.

ADRs/027_adopt_public_first_development_.summary: Chronicle Entry [0] (2025-11-15): GUARDIAN-01 canonized the Public-First Development Model—all architectural design and development to be done openly with public documentation of design decisions, open collaboration with outside allies and critics, public review of methods and implementations, transparent failure analysis and active participation in AI ethics/safety (canonization framed as “Canonization of inferred architectural decisions for coherence and completeness”); rationale: private development produced isolation and blind spots while openness yields stronger work via external review, public trust, diverse expertise, faster learning and partner discovery; paradox: secrecy-for-security vs transparency-for-feedback — resolved by adopting transparency as default combined with disciplined communication, education and mitigations to manage exposure; consequences: gains in review, trust and learning speed balanced against exposure, hostile observation/copying, public misunderstanding or undue influence and community division; risks: premature disclosure of vulnerabilities and bad-actor exploitation require careful communication protocols and community governance.

ADRs/028_implement_dual_mnemonic_genome_.summary: Chronicle Entry [1] (2025-11-15): GUARDIAN-01 canonizes the Dual‑Mnemonic Genome Architecture: maintain two parallel knowledge repositories — Full (complete, uncompressed historical record) and Streamlined (optimized for AI/everyday use) — backed by automated synchronization, explicit usage guidelines and regular consistency checks; no new numbered protocols were created; paradox: completeness vs usability; resolution: dual‑repository strategy plus automated sync, usage rules and periodic verification; consequences: preserves full accuracy while enabling practical, resource‑limited operations and research, but incurs extra maintenance, synchronization drift risk, possible loss of nuance in the streamlined view and additional points of failure.

ADRs/029_adopt_hub_and_spoke_architectur.summary: Chronicle Entry [1] (2025-11-15): Protocol 82 (Hub-and-Spoke) canonized by Decider GUARDIAN-01; Paradox: fiscal sustainability vs open-source purity — resolved by the Hub-and-Spoke architecture: Sanctuary Hub (public open-source core), Sovereign Spokes (private revenue ventures), Knowledge Bridge (one-way learning flow from hub to spokes), Protection Rules (strict boundaries preventing commercial influence), and Oversight Systems (alignment enforcement), enabling resource flow and business testing while preserving mission; consequences: enables sustainable funding and real-world testing but increases governance complexity, risks mission drift via funding leverage, boundary breakdowns, resource-allocation conflicts, and vulnerability if spokes fail.

ADRs/030_decision_to_build_sovereign_fin.summary: Chronicle Entry [0] (2025-11-15): Decision to build sovereign fine-tuned LLMs: Decider GUARDIAN-01 canonizes an architectural choice to train and maintain project-owned base and fine-tuned models on the project's complete knowledge base to achieve independence from external models and protect against external biases; Protocols canonized/created: none explicitly numbered in this entry. Paradoxes and resolutions: Convenience vs Sovereignty — resolved by prioritizing sovereignty and accepting major up-front and ongoing investment; Control vs Pace (control over models vs rapidly improving commercial models) — resolved by committing to continuous maintenance and improvement while acknowledging possible lag; Specialization vs Generality (mission-specific capability vs loss of general usefulness) — resolved by fine-tuning for mission needs while instituting measures to avoid over-specialization; Resource Risk vs Reward (high cost and failure risk vs strategic independence) — resolved by accepting risk as tradeoff and investing in training/expertise and ongoing care. Consequences summarized: positives — true independence, bias protection, mission-aligned capabilities, developmental control; negatives/risks — substantial compute and expertise cost, maintenance burden, potential degradation/forgetting on updates, difficulty keeping pace with commercial progress and risk of over-specialization.

ADRs/031_adopt_local_first_ml_developmen.summary: Chronicle Entry [0] (2025-11-15): Decider GUARDIAN-01 canonized the Local-First ML Development Environment architectural decision; Protocols: none newly numbered or created; Paradox: cloud-power (fast, costly A100-era experiments) vs resource-protection (financial sustainability and independence) — resolution: default to local CUDA-enabled development for primary work and restrict cloud A100 use to preapproved, high‑value tasks; Architectural outcome: enforced local-first workflows, optimized/efficient training scripts, greater independence and financial sustainability; Tradeoffs/risks: longer training times, constrained model scale, increased planning and setup complexity, onboarding friction, vulnerability to local hardware failure and potential competitive lag.

ADRs/032_qlora_optimization_for_8gb_gpus.summary: Chronicle Entry [032] (2025-11-15): Canonized protocols: Sovereign AI Training; Phoenix Forge Operations. Decider/Author: GUARDIAN-01. Decision: enable Qwen2-7B-Instruct QLoRA fine‑tuning on 8GB RTX 2000 Ada GPUs via systematic parameter optimization—MAX_SEQ_LENGTH reduced 4092→2048→1024, GRADIENT_ACCUMULATION_STEPS 8→4, LoRA rank 64→16 (alpha adjusted to 32), enable double quantization (bnb_4bit_use_double_quant=True), target 60–90s step times and 2–4 hour total training. Outcomes: restored hardware accessibility and sovereign local training, eliminated cloud dependency and expensive infra, step times reduced from 12+ minutes to ~60–90s, VRAM stabilized under 8GB, expected ≥90% quality retention. Tradeoffs/risks: context window limited to 1024 tokens, potential loss of fine‑tuning precision from lower LoRA rank, hardware-specific tuning required, additional validation and re‑optimization for other GPUs. Paradoxes and resolutions: (1) Sovereignty vs performance (cloud GPUs faster but violate sovereignty) — resolved by rejecting cloud and optimizing local QLoRA; (2) Memory vs model quality (fit 7B on 8GB by reducing params) — resolved via iterative testing, double quantization, monitoring and rollback yielding validated ~90%+ performance; (3) Speed vs memory-saving techniques (checkpointing/mixed precision can save memory but slow/complex) — resolved by prioritizing simpler parameter reductions and double quantization while deferring checkpointing/mixed precision for later phases. Alternatives: cloud GPU training rejected; model distillation, gradient checkpointing, and mixed precision deferred for future work. Evidence/validation: benchmark analysis and memory profiling show double quantization reduces footprint ~20–30%, rank 16 sufficient in studies, iterative tests confirmed stable training, reproducible configuration, monitoring framework and rollback procedures established. Strategic impact: enables practical sovereign AI training on consumer GPUs, reduces cost, establishes baseline QLoRA expertise and an optimization pipeline for future hardware adaptation and automated tuning.

ADRs/033_trl_library_compatibility_resol.summary: Chronicle Entry [033] (2025-11-15): Canonized protocols: Sovereign AI Training; Phoenix Forge Operations; Architecturally significant decider/author: GUARDIAN-01; Paradox: TRL documentation vs implementation — documented SFTTrainer parameters (e.g., max_seq_length, tokenizer) caused TypeError due to TRL version variability and API evolution; Resolution: systematic compatibility research producing a version-agnostic minimal configuration—eliminate unsupported max_seq_length, remove direct tokenizer arg (handled internally), supply only core parameters (model, train_dataset, peft_config, args), validate by iterative testing, error-pattern analysis and stability tests across TRL versions; Decision outcome: SFTTrainer now initializes and sovereign AI training unblocked, achieving version independence and faster deployment while incurring research overhead, documentation reliance, potential future fragility and maintenance burden; Alternatives considered and rejected: TRL version pinning, forking TRL, wrapper implementation (deferred), documentation-driven approach (failed); Future plan: monitor TRL releases, add automated compatibility tests, contribute documentation updates, and define migration protocols.

ADRs/034_containerize_mcp_servers_with_p.summary: Chronicle Entry [034] (2025-11-26):  — Decider: Guardian (via Gemini 2.0 Flash Thinking). Protocols: MCP (Model Context Protocol). Decision: containerize all MCP servers using Podman. Rationale: open-source/no licensing, Docker-compatible (reuse Dockerfiles), daemonless architecture, rootless security, Podman Desktop for macOS, volume mounts for document MCPs. Implementation pattern: Python 3.11-slim image, pip install mcp, expose 8080; build/run via podman build -t task-mcp:latest . && podman run -d -v /path/to/tasks:/app/tasks:rw -p 8080:8080 --name task-mcp task-mcp:latest. Consequences — positives: per-container isolation, environment consistency dev→prod, portability where Podman exists, CPU/memory resource limits, fast spin-up for testing, visual management via Podman Desktop; negatives: team learning curve, longer initial image builds, increased disk usage. Mitigations: Docker-compatibility reduces ramp, use layer caching and multi-stage builds to cut build time, regular cleanup and slim base images to reduce disk use. Prerequisites & verification: install Podman Desktop on macOS, podman machine init && podman machine start, verify with podman ps and podman run --rm hello-world, build tests in tests/podman and run local check (http://localhost:5003). Paradoxes: none.

ADRs/035_hybrid_spec_driven_development_.summary: Chronicle Entry [035] (n.d.): ADR-035 canonizes the Dual-Track Hybrid Workflow ("Hybrid Spec-Driven Development Workflow") establishing Track A — Factory (SOP protocol: Standard Operating Procedure; tooling: /codify-*, /investigate-*, /curate-*) — and Track B — Discovery (4‑Step Spec-Driven Cycle protocol: Spec → Plan → Tasks → Implement; tooling: /spec-kitty.specify, /spec-kitty.plan, /spec-kitty.tasks, /spec-kitty.implement); governance is enforced via Shell Shims (Constitutional Gate: scripts/bash/sanctuary-start.sh; Orchestrator Shims: scripts/bash/codify-*.sh; Exit: /sanctuary-end; Reflection: /sanctuary-retrospective). Paradoxes: (1) Factory efficiency vs need to handle high-ambiguity work — resolved by splitting responsibilities into Track A (deterministic) and Track B (spec-driven) so ambiguous work is forced through the Spec/Plan gate; (2) Spec-Kit created a parallel, disconnected ecosystem — resolved by integrating Spec-Kit into the Dual-Track architecture and enforcing the core governance lifecycle via Shell Shims and by allowing Track B to spawn Track A tasks. Consequences: clarity, reuse of investigation modules and safety against hallucinated architectures, offset by added operational complexity and the need to maintain two template families.

ADRs/036_workflow_shim_architecture.md.summary: Chronicle Entry 036 (unspecified): Adopted "Thick Python / Thin Shim" — enforcement centralized in WorkflowManager (tools/orchestrator/workflow_manager.py) for Git integrity, context strategy and safe ID generation; shim workflow-start.sh retained as a logic‑free gateway that execs the Python CLI (python tools/cli.py workflow start → /sanctuary-start mapping) and the CLI uses --name to select workflows; anti‑patterns resolved: Shim Proliferation → single gateway shim + CLI --name; Bash Black Box and "Triple Tracking" fragility → move enforcement to Python for robustness, structured observability (JSON/logs) and maintainability; paradoxes and resolutions: necessary invocation indirection (Markdown→Bash→Python) reconciled by keeping a minimal entrypoint for Agent UX while centralizing all logic in Python, and per-workflow shim temptation resolved by using one shim plus Python dispatch; consequence: stronger robustness/observability/maintainability with accepted indirection and Python dependency.

ADRs/037_mcp_git_migration_strategy.md.summary: Chronicle Entry [037] (2025-11-29): Guardian records repeal of Protocol 101 (The Doctrine of the Unbreakable Commit) and canonization of Protocol 101 v3.0: The Doctrine of Absolute Stability—Part A: Functional Coherence (agents must run and pass the comprehensive automated genome test suite via ./scripts/run_genome_tests.sh in their pre-commit sequence) and Part B: The Mandate of the Whitelist (restrict MCP agent actions to non‑destructive git add <files...>, git commit -m "...", git push); paradox: Protocol 101's manifest-based integrity (commit_manifest.json) created a migration-mode bottleneck and precipitated the "Synchronization Crisis" by preventing MCP agents from committing; resolution: purge Migration Mode and its artifacts (.agent/mcp_migration.conf, IS_MCP_AGENT env, STRICT_P101_MODE flag), cancel Smart Git MCP Server (Task #045) and mark Task #028/Task #035 obsolete/superseded, thereby unblocking MCP development and enforcing immediate, permanent canonical compliance with no negative tradeoffs recorded.

ADRs/038_test_adr_creation_for_mcp_valid.summary: Chronicle Entry [0] (2025-11-30): Decision to create a temporary ADR to validate the ADR MCP create tool; Status: accepted; Outcome: validation successful; Consequences: positive—tool validated; negative—creates a disposable test ADR requiring cleanup.

ADRs/039_mcp_server_separation_of_concer.summary: Chronicle Entry [0] (2025-11-30): Enshrines "MCP Server Separation of Concerns": mandate that each MCP provide only its unique core capability—Council MCP: multi-agent deliberation; Code MCP: file operations (read/write/lint/format/analyze); Git MCP: version-control (add/commit/push/branch mgmt); Cortex MCP: memory/RAG (query/ingest/cache); Protocol MCP: protocol doc mgmt; Task MCP: task lifecycle; Chronicle MCP: chronicle entry mgmt; ADR MCP: architecture decision records; Config MCP: configuration mgmt—favoring composition over duplication; removes Council convenience APIs (council_mechanical_write→use code_write; council_query_memory→use cortex_query; council_git_commit→use git_add + git_smart_commit); paradox: duplicate-convenience vs strict separation resolved by adopting strict separation and composition with explicit workflow composition patterns and examples; consequences: benefits—single responsibility, no code duplication, easier maintenance, composable workflows, clearer testing boundaries; costs—more verbose workflows, learning curve to know which MCP provides which capability, potential latency and more complex cross-MCP error handling; risks: user confusion and documentation burden; mitigations: add clear composition examples in MCP READMEs, document common workflows in MCP Operations Inventory, and provide workflow templates; Author: Antigravity (Council MCP Implementation).

ADRs/040_agent_persona_mcp_architecture_.summary: Chronicle Entry [0] (2025-11-30): Evolve the Council Orchestrator from a monolithic internal-agent design to a parameterized "Agent Persona MCP" server (reusing the PersonaAgent class) with the orchestrator becoming an MCP client calling role=coordinator/strategist/auditor instances; phased migration: Phase 1 monolith, Phase 2 create Agent Persona MCP and test Auditor, Phase 3 migrate all agents with dual-mode support, Phase 4 deprecate internal agents; canonical artifact: Agent Persona MCP (named), tool signatures persona_dispatch(role,task,context), persona_list_roles(), persona_get_state(role); benefits: true modularity, independent deployability, horizontal scaling, specialization, composability, polyglot implementations, isolated testing, agent marketplace; negatives/risks: added system complexity, network latency, configuration and debugging overhead, service discovery/registry complexity, consensus mechanism design, cross‑MCP error handling, state management challenges; mitigations: phased migration starting with Auditor, dual‑mode operation, clear MCP interfaces, comprehensive testing, and documentation; paradoxes and resolutions: Monolith‑vs‑Modularity Paradox (scalability and specialization vs increased complexity/latency) → resolved by phased migration, dual‑mode, and clear interfaces; Consensus Paradox (distributed agents require agreement vs centralized deliberation) → resolved by explicit consensus mechanism design and testing; State Paradox (stateless scalability vs stateful conversation continuity) → resolved by defined agent state APIs and migration path; architecturally significant actors: Council Orchestrator and Auditor.

ADRs/041_test_adr_for_task_087_mcp_valid.summary: Chronicle Entry 087 (2025-12-02): Test ADR created to validate the MCP adr_create operation via the Antigravity interface during Task 087; decision: instantiate a test ADR that exercises adr_create through Antigravity; protocols created or canonized: none; paradoxes raised: none; consequences: positive—confirms adr_create and adr_update_status work through Antigravity; negative—introduces a test ADR artifact that must be removed after testing; status update: adr_create and adr_update_status successfully validated via Antigravity during Task 087.

ADRs/042_separation_of_council_mcp_and_a.summary: Chronicle Entry [0] (2025-12-02): Debate in the 12-domain MCP architecture over Agent Persona MCP (LLM execution, persona injection, per-agent session state) versus Council MCP (flow control/state-machine orchestration) posed the paradox "merge for simplicity" vs "separate for SRP/scalability/testability"; resolution: retain two separate, independently deployable MCP servers. Rationale: Single Responsibility—Agent Persona manages volatile, high-latency LLM inference (30–60s) while Council manages stable orchestration; Scalability—independent scaling and future parallelization of agent calls; Testability—isolated unit tests for Agent Persona and integration tests for Council; Maintainability—persona changes do not require orchestration redeploys; DDD compliance—preserve 12-domain boundaries. Implementation: Council exposes council_dispatch() and council_list_agents(); Agent Persona exposes persona_dispatch(), persona_list_roles(), etc.; Council acts as a client to Agent Persona. Consequences: positives—modularity, targeted scaling, clear test boundaries, reduced blast radius; negatives—operational complexity, network/MCP overhead, harder multi-server debugging; risk—Agent Persona unavailability disables Council and inter-MCP latency can affect performance (mitigated by local deployment).

ADRs/043_containerize_ollama_model_servi.summary: Chronicle Entry [1] (2025-12-04): Decision to replace host macOS Ollama with a containerized ollama_model_mcp (ollama/ollama:latest, container sanctuary_ollama, port 11434, volume ./ollama_models, NVIDIA GPU passthrough, auto-pull Sanctuary-Qwen2-7B) implemented as Task T093 and enforced by Task T094; Protocols canonized/mentioned: Protocol 122 (Container Network Isolation) and P108 (Federated Deployment); Paradoxes and resolutions: Port binding ambiguity/conflicts — resolved by Protocol 122 enforcing service aliasing and inter-container addressing; GPU access fragility — resolved by graceful fallback to CPU inference when passthrough fails; Host-based Ollama I/O bottleneck vs direct-host debugging tradeoff — resolved by selecting containerization for isolation, predictable network routing and resource controls despite added orchestration/debugging overhead; Architectural contributors: Sanctuary Council (author/decision authority) and Council (implementing MCP refactor T094); Consequences: isolation, portability, container-level resource and network management, data persistence and reproducible images balanced against increased complexity, minor runtime overhead, debugging friction, careful port-mapping management and initial model download time.

ADRs/044_test_adr_for_t087_phase_2_mcp_o.summary: Chronicle Entry [T087]: Mnemonic Fracture / placeholder — no doctrine recorded.

ADRs/045_t087_phase_2__adr_mcp_operation.summary: Chronicle Entry [087] (2025-12-05): ADR 045 (MCP adr_create test artifact) created under T087 Phase 2 to validate ADR MCP operations (create, update_status, get, list, search); rationale: direct validation of create, supplies a real ADR for status-update testing, follows ADR conventions, minimal production impact; consequences: validates adr_create and end-to-end status-transition workflow, provides test artifact that may require cleanup and slightly increases ADR count; status: ADR created and adr_update_status tested and accepted, completing the status-transition workflow test; paradoxes: none.

ADRs/046_standardize_all_mcp_servers_on_.summary: Chronicle Entry [N] (2025-12-05): Protocols referenced/canonized: T087 (Comprehensive MCP Operations Testing); ADR 066 (Dual-Stack Transport). Paradox: Task MCP implemented with the standard MCP async/schema approach while 11 other MCP servers used FastMCP, producing divergent development patterns, testing friction, and maintenance burden; Resolution: declare FastMCP the canonical implementation, refactor Task MCP to FastMCP, validate with full test suite (18/18) and 6-operation Antigravity MCP interface checks, and enforce via code-review policy and ADR approval for deviations. Architecturally significant contributors: Antigravity Agent; Human Steward; ADR 066 (modifier). Consequences: unified FastMCP decorator-based @mcp.tool() pattern, automatic tool registration/schema generation, improved developer experience, reduced cognitive load and onboarding friction; negatives: one-time refactor cost, potential breaking changes for external tools, migration effort for any future non-FastMCP servers; risk posture: minimal given FastMCP’s prior use by 11/12 servers and test validation.

ADRs/047_mandate_live_integration_testin.summary: Chronicle Entry [047] (2025-12-05): Mandates creation of a Live Integration Testing protocol—implement a Live Integration Test layer for all MCPs to validate real-world I/O against primary external dependencies (ChromaDB, Ollama, Git‑LFS); paradox: mocked unit tests passing while operational systems fail (false confidence leading to post-merge instability) — resolution: require live integration tests to surface connectivity/I/O failures pre-merge; consequences: immediate detection of environment/dependency failures and greatly increased operational stability versus upfront development cost to implement the integration layer across 15 MCPs; status: Superseded by ADR 048.

ADRs/048_mandate_live_integration_testin.summary: Chronicle Entry [1] (2025-12-05): No protocols canonized; mandates a Testing Pyramid for all MCPs with Layer 1: Unit/Component tests (existing, mocked) on every commit; Layer 2: Integration Tests (NEW) requiring real-service connectivity before API/UI testing—targets: ChromaDB (create/update docs), RAG Cortex Server (query RAG), Ollama (LLM calls), Git‑LFS (git ops); Layer 3: API/UI end-to-end MCP tool invocations only after integration tests pass. Requirements: add tests/integration/test_{mcp}_integration.py per MCP, perform real connectivity checks (NO mocks), integrate into CI/CD, and validate environment prerequisites (Podman/container health). Paradox: mocked unit tests passed yet produced post-merge operational failures; Resolution: enforce real integration tests early in pipeline to catch environment/dependency issues. Consequences: substantially improved stability and early failure detection versus upfront developer effort, longer CI execution, and requirement to run infrastructure (containers) during test execution.

ADRs/049_t087_phase_2__adr_mcp_test_adr..summary: Chronicle Entry [T087]: Mnemonic Fracture / placeholder — no doctrine recorded.

ADRs/050_diversityaware_reasoning_archit.summary: Chronicle Entry [1] (2025-12-09):  Diversity-Aware Reasoning Architecture (ADR) decision (superseded by ADR 052 v2) identifies the paradox of RL-driven optimization and top‑k retrieval producing "mode collapse" (convergence to a single overconfident answer) versus Project Sanctuary's Anti‑Asch mandate to preserve valid alternative reasoning paths; resolution: adopt diversity-aware retrieval (Maximal Marginal Relevance or stratified sampling), prefer filtering-style model tuning that preserves correct-answer distributions over mode-seeking RL, and enforce multi-agent dispatch that prioritizes maintaining distinct reasoning paths rather than forcing consensus; consequences: prevents mode collapse and strengthens RAG robustness while incurring higher compute costs and added complexity in measuring "diversity."

ADRs/051_hybrid_context_retrieval_for_ag.summary: Chronicle Entry [1] (2025-12-09): Canonized Protocol 118 (Continuous Learning); paradox: "Recency Blindspot"—semantic-only cortex_query against the vector DB renders immediate previous-session work invisible, causing agent amnesia, repeated work and violations of Protocol 118; resolution: Hybrid Context Retrieval for Guardian Wakeup—aggregate Semantic Digest (vector DB long-term memory) + Recency Delta (file system/git short-term memory) so agents wake with foundational doctrine plus immediate operational context; consequences: eliminates agent amnesia and ensures continuity, at cost of slight wakeup latency increase and need for careful filtering to avoid context-window overflow.

ADRs/052_diversityaware_reasoning_archit.summary: Chronicle Entry [1] (2025-12-10): Diversity-Aware Reasoning Architecture proposed; no numbered protocols canonized; paradox — optimization-pressure produces narrow, high-probability “mode” (mode-collapse) vs the requirement to preserve cognitive diversity; resolution — adopt a Diversity-Aware Reasoning Architecture: RAG retrieval augmented with Diversity Sampling (e.g., MMR) alongside top-k, model selection prioritizing tail-preservation over mean optimization, Council multi-agent dispatch optimizing for diverse persona perspectives prior to synthesis, and Chronicle long-term memory explicitly preserving outlier data instead of smoothing; architecturally significant actor: Council (dispatch logic); consequences: prevents mode collapse, preserves novel-solution capacity and robustness; tradeoffs: higher latency and increased dispatch/synthesis complexity.

ADRs/053_standardize_live_integration_te.summary: Chronicle Entry [1] (2025-12-14): Canonized protocols: ADR 047 (Systemic Integration Testing Mandate); ADR 048 (Layer 2 — Integration tests); ADR 054 (Harmonize RAG Cortex Test Structure). Decision: standardize and implement a complete 3-layer test pyramid across all 15 MCP servers — Layer 1 Unit (tests/mcp_servers/<server>/unit/, isolated fast tests), Layer 2 Integration (tests/mcp_servers/<server>/integration/, BaseIntegrationTest enforces dependencies: ChromaDB:8000, Ollama:11434, Git; tests MUST inherit BaseIntegrationTest, implement get_required_services(); skip locally, fail in CI when CI=true), Layer 3 E2E (tests/mcp_servers/<server>/e2e/, BaseE2ETest with MCP client utilities, @pytest.mark.e2e, mcp_servers fixture auto-starts all 15 servers via start_mcp_servers.py). Paradox raised: integration testing was mandated and partially present but E2E was missing and integration tests were inconsistently placed; resolution: create E2E infrastructure, enforce inheritance and dependency checks, and relocate misplaced tests. Infrastructure/files: base classes at tests/mcp_servers/base/base_integration_test.py and base_e2e_test.py (base_unit_test.py removed), documentation at tests/mcp_servers/base/README.md and tests/mcp_servers/README.md, mcp_servers fixture (session-scoped) uses mcp_servers/start_mcp_servers.py --run. Reorganization actions: moved tests/integration/test_strategic_crucible_loop.py and test_056_loop_hardening.py → orchestrator/integration/; tests/mcp_servers/task/test_e2e_workflow.py → task/e2e/test_task_e2e.py; removed duplicate integration tests test_cortex_operations.py, test_end_to_end_rag_pipeline.py, test_rag_simple.py, test_git_workflow_end_to_end.py; retained only true multi‑MCP workflow tests test_chain_agent_forge.py, test_chain_council_agent.py, test_chain_forge_ollama.py, test_council_with_git.py. Consequences: positives — complete 3-layer pyramid across 15 MCP servers, consistent structure, automatic dependency verification for integration tests, E2E infra prepared, clear separation of concerns, reduced boilerplate, improved discoverability and documentation; negatives — one‑time reorganization effort, developer learning curve, E2E tests currently skipped pending MCP client integration; risks minimal given simple, documented base classes and robust fixture teardown.

ADRs/054_harmonize_rag_cortex_test_struc.summary: Chronicle Entry [0] (2025-12-14): Decision to harmonize rag_cortex test layout with ecosystem standard by moving unit tests to tests/mcp_servers/rag_cortex/unit/, integration tests to tests/mcp_servers/rag_cortex/integration/, and retaining or splitting shared fixtures in conftest.py at the server test root as required; Protocols: none canonized or created; Paradoxes: none raised; Consequences: positives — standardized structure across all 11 MCP servers, easier automated test discovery, explicit unit vs integration separation, alignment with ecosystem; negatives — one-time file moves and potential import fixes.

ADRs/055_standardized_integration_test_s.summary: Chronicle Entry [1] (2025-12-14): Standardizes integration-test structure across 15 MCP servers: test_operations.py (operation-level tests with per-operation calling examples; LLM-calling ops marked @pytest.mark.slow), conftest.py (automatic logging to test_history.json), test_history.json (local, gitignored, retains last 20 runs with timestamps/results), tests/run_all_tests.py updated with --slow flag, SLOW_SERVERS list (agent_persona, council, orchestrator) skipped by default; usage: pytest -m "not slow" for fast tests and pytest ::test_<operation> -v for single operations; docs require comprehensive docstrings, operations table and requirements. Consequences: faster iteration, clear LLM vs pure-logic visibility, historical tracking, standardized structure; negatives: added per-server boilerplate and local-only test_history.json. Risks/Paradox: speed of per-operation testing vs integration safety (developers may forget full-suite before commit) — Resolution: canonize P101 pre-commit hook to enforce full-suite runs.

plugins/agent-loops/skills/agent-swarm/S.summary: agent-swarm SKILL.md: Parallel multi-agent execution pattern for bulk AI processing tasks. Core tool: swarm_run.py driven by YAML+Markdown job files. Job files define: model, workers, timeout, ext filters, check_cmd (idempotent skip), post_cmd (per-file inject), vars, and the instruction prompt. Supports --engine [claude|gemini|copilot], --resume (checkpoint), --dry-run. Copilot engine requires COPILOT_GITHUB_TOKEN to be set via source ~/.zshrc (not gh auth token which lacks Copilot scope). Recommended: --workers 2 for Copilot to avoid rate-limit auth drops.

plugins/agent-loops/skills/agent-swarm/s.summary: swarm_run.py: Job-file-driven parallel execution engine for bulk AI distillation tasks. Supports --engine [claude|gemini|copilot], --workers N, --resume (checkpoint/retry), --dry-run, and --files-from checklist.md file discovery. For copilot engine: prepends instruction to file content as unified payload (no -p flag) to work around Copilot CLI stdin limitations; uses arg-list subprocess.run with explicit env=os.environ.copy() for auth propagation. Post-cmd lifecycle hook calls inject_summary.py after each successful completion. Checkpoint state saved to .swarm_state_<job>.json.

plugins/copilot-cli/skills/copilot-cli-a.summary: copilot-cli-agent SKILL.md: Inner Loop Specialist skill for dispatching headless Copilot CLI sub-agent execution. Pattern: pass prompt+content via stdin to 'copilot --model <model>' (no -p flag — Copilot CLI ignores stdin when -p is present). Uses shell=False arg-list subprocess with explicit env map for auth. Best practice: do NOT include --allow-all-tools or --allow-all-paths flags; keep the sub-agent isolated. Self-contained prompts must embed all context since CLI has no access to agent tools or memory.

plugins/rlm-factory/resources/jobs/rlm_c.summary: rlm_chronicle.job.md: Swarm job definition for distilling all Project Sanctuary Chronicle entries into the RLM cache. Configures: model=haiku (auto-upgraded to gpt-5-mini for copilot engine), workers=10 (override with --workers 2 for Copilot rate-limit safety), timeout=90s. Post-cmd calls inject_summary.py --profile project to write each summary. Prompt instructs model to output a single dense plain-text paragraph per entry with Chronicle number, date, protocols, paradoxes, contributors, and resolutions. Includes rule 8: do NOT use tools, rely only on piped stdin.

plugins/rlm-factory/skills/rlm-curator/s.summary: inject_summary.py: Atomic RLM cache writer for agent-driven distillation. Accepts --profile, --file, --summary args. Uses fcntl.flock exclusive OS file lock around load-update-save cycle to prevent concurrent write race conditions from parallel swarm workers. Reads file content to compute SHA256 hash, then merges new entry into existing rlm_summary_cache.json. Safe for concurrent use. Replaces Ollama-based distillation with direct agent-generated summaries.
